Tel.: +86 10 67396092; fax: +86 10 67396085. Graphical abstract Alkali metals were considered to be poisonous to not only V-based catalysts but also Mn-based catalysts. Catalysts of Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 (M=Fe, Ni) prepared by co-precipitation method for low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3 under the influence of alkali metals were investigated in this study. As the experiment result, the low temperature SCR activity showed greatly enhanced which near at 150°C the substitution of the Fe content to Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst could obviously increased to 87% without alkali metals and the best NO conversion of Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 catalyst under alkali metals in the temperature range of 150–300°C was 88% (K/Mn=0.5). The addition of alkali metal not only generates physical adsorption but also reduces the surface chemisorbed oxygen and causes a decline in Brønsted acid sites. These catalysts showed higher SCR activity and better resistance to alkali poisoning, because the characteristics of the large surface area and pore volume, the increased chemisorbed oxygen, the enhanced oxidative ability of manganese species and the presence of many weak acid sites. Keywords Low temperature SCR Mn-Ce/TiO2 Alkali metals Weak acid sites 1 Introduction Recently, NO x emission from cement industry has attracted much attention in addition to that from thermal power industries and the automobile industry for increasing concerning on quality of the atmospheric environment [1–4]. Various methods, such as multistage combustion (MSC), Low-NO x Burner (LNB), SCR and SNCR technology have been applied to controlling and reducing NO x emission in cement industry [5]. Among these methods, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 as reductant is an effective technology for removal of NO x from stationary sources. The activity of SCR catalyst is one of the most key factors in the process of NO x reduction. While, the extensive use of dry process and substitute fuels in cement kilns will lead to the increase of alkali content in clinker and cement, which easily cause catalysts poisoned and the activity decreased. The high content of alkali metal compounds also exist in biomass combustion plants, such as straws and municipal waste plants, in addition to cement industry [6]. The commercial catalyst used in industries is mainly based on V2O5/TiO2 [7], which needs to perform at higher temperature for NO conversion at least 300°C. Thus, this SCR technology can only be used in relatively cleaning surroundings without fine particles and dust [8] A series of other new catalysts including all kinds of transition metal (V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu oxides) on different commercial supports, such as silica and alumina, have been studied for improving the activity of the catalyst and decreasing its reaction temperature. Among them, MnO x /TiO2, MnO x /Al2O3, MnO x /SiO2 and MnO x /AC (activated carbon) [9–12] have been demonstrated to show good low-temperature activity for SCR of denitration with NH3. The presence of ceria element can promote the oxidization of NO into NO2 because of its oxygen storage and redox properties by ceria via the redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+ [13–15]. Wu et al. [16] prepared ceria modified MnO x /TiO2 and found that the introduction of Ce improved the oxygen mobility and the NH3 chemisorption ability of the catalysts, leading to the improvement of its SCR activity. Water soluble or ion exchange of alkali metal (K+ and Na+) has high liquidity in flue gas, which neutralizes acid sites on the surface of catalysts. Numerous studies [17–24] have been performed to discover the influence of alkali metals on V2O5-based catalyst, which found that potassium compounds reduced the number of chemical adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst and the catalyst surface Brønsted acid was changed by chemical. Less information is posted on the alkali metal deactivation of Mn-based catalysts. The objective of this paper is to study that the influence of alkali metals on the catalysts based on Mn-Ce/TiO2 with the addition of transition metals for removing NO x with NH3 at low temperature. Special attention was paid to the deactivation characters of potassium ions on the Mn-Ce/TiO2 based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method. After aqueous solutions of titanium sulphate, manganese acetate and nitrates (Ce, Fe, Ni) were pre-mixed, carbamide solution, ammonia (25wt.%) and hydrogen peroxide were continuously added to the mixed solution. The precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed using distilled water for two times and ethanol for two times. The mixture was dried at 105°C for 12h, and then, the solid were calcined at 450°C for 4h in air in a muffle furnace. 2.2 Alkali poisoning K2O poisoning experiments with the molar ratios (K/Mn=0.5) of K/Mn were prepared by impregnation of catalysts with potassium nitrate. The mixture was mixed under stirring at room temperature for 1h continuously and dried at 105°C for 6h. Then, the solid samples were calcined at 450°C for 4h in air in a muffle furnace. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The crystal structures of the prepared catalyst were determined by X-ray diffraction using a Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffract meter (Shimadzu Corporation, Japan) with a Cu-Kα radiation (wavelength 1.5406Å). The BET specific surface areas and pore-size measurements were performed by nitrogen adsorption at 77K using a Micrometrics Tristar 3020 (Micrometrics, USA). Catalytic materials were pretreated at 473K under vacuum, and the analysis of the supports was done at 77K under vacuum. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the surface atomic state of catalyst with Al Kα X-rays (Thermo ESCALAB 250, USA). The concentrations of Mn, Ti, Ce and O on catalysts surface were calculated from the peak areas ratios of the samples. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) were carried out on the 1100 Series TPDRO (Thermo, USA) instrument. The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurement was carried out using 50mg catalysts. Prior to TPR experiments, catalysts were pretreated in a N2 stream at 200°C for 1h, and cooled to 100°C. TPR was carried out up to 700°C in a flow of H2 at a rate of 5°Cmin−1. The hydrogen consumption was calculated by integration of the corresponding signal intensities. For NH3-TPD experiments, after pretreated in N2 at 500°C for 1h, catalysts were saturated with anhydrous NH3 (4% in N2) at a flow rate of 30mlmin−1 for about 30min. Desorption was carried out by heating the sample in N2 (30mlmin−1) from 100°C to 800°C with a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1. DRIFT measurements were performed on a VERTEX 70 (Bruker, Germany) spectrometers. Prior to each experiment, the catalysts were pretreated at 450°C in N2 environment for 2h, then cooled to the desired temperature. The reaction conditions were controlled as follows: 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3 and N2 balance. 2.4 Activity measurements SCR activity measurements were carried out in a self-made fixed-bed quartz reactor containing 3mL catalyst. The reaction temperature was measured by the thermocouple projecting directly into the center of the reactor. The reactant gases of 1000ppm NO, 1000ppm NH3, 5% O2 and N2 balance were quantitative regulated by gas flowmeters. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 27000h−1, and the catalytic temperature was at the range of 80–300°C. The inlet and outlet concentrations of NO and NO2 were measured by the NO-NO2-NO x Model 42i-HLinstrument (Thermo, USA). The percent conversion of NO was calculated as follows: NO conversion = 100 × ( [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out ) [ NO ] in where [NO]in is the inlet concentration of NO, and [NO]out is the outlet concentration of NO. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the NO x conversion with increasing temperature in NH3-SCR reaction over Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-M-K/TiO2 catalysts (M=Fe, Ni). As can be seen from Fig. 1, the substitution of transition metals could indeed influence the SCR activity of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. When partial M (M=Fe, Ni) was doped, the NO x percent conversion at the low temperature range of 150–270°C increased obviously. Mn-Ce/TiO2 with doped Fe showed the highest activity, comparing with NiO. Near at 150°C the substitution of Fe content to Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst could obviously enhance the NO x conversions (87%). Also, with the increase of temperature, the NO conversion of the samples increased gradually and the highest value is 85% at the temperature of 300°C with the addition of NiO. In a previous study by Qi and Yang [25], they also observed the Mn-Fe/TiO2 catalyst showed the best activity among other type catalysts in the SCR reaction. Catalysts containing alkali metal (K2O) was prepared by the impregnation method with KNO3 as the precursors. After calcination the alkali nitrates decomposed and the alkali metals existed as alkali cations (K+), which would interact with adjacent oxygen atoms [26]. The activity of the catalysts doped K+ was much smaller than that of the catalysts without alkali metals as indicated in Fig. 1. However, the NO x conversion of the Mn-Ce-M-K/TiO2 showed higher than that of the samples without alkali metals below the temperature of 90°C and the NO conversions of all the K+ poisoning catalysts drop to the lowest value at the temperature of about 150°C. 3.2 X-ray diffraction The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of various Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 catalysts (M=Fe, Ni) samples calcined at 450°C are shown in Figs. 2 and 3 . The XRD patterns of these samples, Mn3O4 and anatase TiO2 can be detected. However, the cerium oxide phase was not detected by XRD. This further indicated that strong interactions existed between cerium oxides and anatase TiO2. High dispersion of MnO x can increase the amount of oxygen vacancy, resulting in increase of catalytic activity [27]. It can be observed that the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts have the highest XRD intensity and sharp peaks, which mean that transition metal oxides can decrease the crystalline. As we can be clear from X-ray diffraction patterns of fresh and poisoning catalyst, that K+ cation can also decrease the crystalline. However, K+ cation was not detected for Mn-Ce-M-K/TiO2 catalysts. It may be the case that most of the KNO3 were decomposed to amorphous K2O and it was highly dispersed in structure without bringing changes to the crystalline phase of the catalyst. The particle sizes of the catalysts were calculated based on the half-width of the XRD peaks of the (101) plane, using Scherrer's equation. The values of the crystallite sizes of the catalysts for Mn-Ce/TiO2 Mn-Ce-Fe/TiO2, Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2, Mn-Ce-K/TiO2, Mn-Ce-Fe-K/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-Ni-K/TiO2 were 10.197nm, 8.722nm, 9.467nm, 9.303nm, 9.190nm and 8.457nm, respectively. Mn-Ce-Fe/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-Ni-K/TiO2 catalysts have smaller particle size consistent with the NO x conversion. 3.3 Surface area and pore-size distribution The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume and pore size of the catalysts were shown in Table 1 . The surface area of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst was101.4m2/g, and the pore volume was 38.5×10−2 cm3/g. When partial transition metals were doped, the surface area and the pore volume increased slightly. It could be observed that a lot of micro pore could be preserved in the catalysts with the addition of M (M=Fe, Ni), and the surface area was larger than that of Mn-Ce/TiO2. Therefore, the addition of transition metals had changed the nano-structure of the catalyst [28]. However, comparison of the fresh samples with the deactivated samples indicates that the surface areas decreased with increasing alkali metal loading, but no significant change in average pore diameter occurred. Pore volumes of the deactivated catalysts decreased with the doping of alkali metal. These results indicate that alkali metals introduced pore blocking somewhat, leading to the deactivation of the catalysts [29]. Fig. 4 shows N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore diameter distributions of catalysts. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption results suggest that the isothermal type of IV, all hysteresis loops resemble the H1-type, which indicate that catalysts have the mesoporous structure and the pores are well-distributed and narrow. Pore size distributions of the samples are in the mesopores range between 8 and 30nm. Among them, the Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 catalyst is bimodal mesoporous structure and the maximum abundant of pore size is 12nm and 18nm, while the poisoning catalyst is unimodal. The positions of the second peak appear in lower temperatures with Mn-Ce-Fe/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2. It is indicated that the catalyst with a support of mixed transition metal has the best performance in the lower temperature range. As we can see, after K+ cation was added, the adsorption quantity of the poisoning catalysts is decreased obviously and the height of the peak dropped, which is attributed to the deposit and coverage of K2O on catalysts. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS spectra of Mn 2p, Ce 3d and O 2s for the Mn-Ce/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-K/TiO2 catalysts were presented in Figs. 5–8 . XPS results of Mn 2p in prepared samples are shown in Fig. 5. The main peak of the Mn 2p3/2 state becomes broader and shifts to higher binding energy with increasing transition metal which may be ascribed to the formation of solid solution on the interface of catalysts with transition metal doping. Two main peaks of pure MnO2 (Mn4+) sample ascribed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 were observed at 642.1 and 653.6eV, respectively. In Mn 2p spectra, the binding energies of Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 peaks were located at 641.7 and 653.6eV, respectively, which are characteristic of a mixed-valence manganese system (MnO2 and Mn3O4) [30]. However, as showed in Fig. 5, Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst showed the Mn 2p3/2 peak at around 641.6eV, which is close to the peak attributed to Mn2O3 (641.5eV) [31]. Thus, Mn loaded onto the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts may also exist in a form of Mn2O3. Kapteijn et al. [32] investigated NO conversions over the pure manganese oxides at low temperature, and found that the NO conversions decreased in the order of MnO2 >Mn5O8 >Mn2O3 >Mn3O4. The XPS result of observed Ce 3d spectra is shown in Fig. 6. According to previous reports [33,34], XPS peaks denoted as V (882.5eV), V″ (888.8eV), and V‴ (898.4eV) and U (901.0eV), U″ (907.5eV), and U‴ (916.7eV) were assigned to Ce4+ species while U0 (898.8eV), U′ (903.5eV), V0 (880.3eV), and V′ (884.9eV) were attributed to Ce3+ species. Ce4+ and Ce3+ were considered to coexist on the surface of the catalysts in our work. The ratio of Ce4+/Ce3+ was calculated based on the XPS spectra. The results showed that the ratio of Ce4+/Ce3+ was about 1.57, 2.27 and 2.31 for Mn-Ce/TiO2, Mn-Ce-Fe/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2, respectively. We could learn from the results that Ce4+ oxidation state was predominant, and Ce3+ was weak compared with Ce4+. In the O 1s spectra of Figs. 7 and 8, it could be seen that the intensity of the peak around Oβ can be due to the lattice oxygen in the metal oxides decreased greatly with the addition of transition metal. As showed in Table 2 , comparison of the fresh samples with the deactivated samples indicates that the oxygen concentration decreased on the surface of the catalysts with increasing alkali metal loading. Ot was composed of lattice oxygen O2− (denoted as Oβ) and surface chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα) such as O2 2− or O− belonging to defect-oxide or hydroxyl-like group [35]. The relatively high concentration ratio of Oα/(Oα +Oβ) on the catalyst surface could be correlated with high SCR activity. The addition of transition metal will increase the amount of oxygen vacancy. Potassium ions have similar ionic radius with that of oxygen ions, and easily occupy the oxygen vacancy. The ratio of (Oα/Oα +Oβ) for fresh catalyst is higher than poisoning catalyst, suggesting that the fresh catalyst has more surface chemisorbed oxygen. Larger amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen on the surface causes the formation of the Brønsted acid sites. Table 2 shows the atomic concentrations on the surface of the catalysts determined by XPS. The molar ratios of Ce/Ti and Ni/Ti in the bulk were 0.07 and 0.07, respectively, while the ratios of Ce/Ti and Ni/Ti on the surface of the catalysts increased greatly according to the XPS results, indicating that Ce and Ni atoms were easy to disperse on the surface of the catalysts. Therefore, with increase of Ce and Ni, the concentration of Mn decreased on the surface of the catalysts. It indicated that Ce and Ni are more easily dispersed than Mn on the surface of the catalysts. 3.5 H2-TPR analysis All H2-consumption peaks are showed in Figs. 9 and 10 , which could be attributed to the reduction of manganese species. As we can see from Fig. 9, there were two main peaks between 300 and 600°C. These peaks may consist of the following successive reduction steps: MnO2 to Mn2O3, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 to MnO [36,37]. In addition to the TPR result, the X-ray diffraction data also showed the existence of Mn3O4. It indicates that MnO2 might be present in an amorphous state. Among the different types of manganese oxide catalysts, it was reported [38,32] that the amorphous manganese oxide had good performance in SCR reaction, while the crystalline one contributed little to activity. At low temperature, the manganese reduction peak is observed at 417°C in Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst. The addition of Fe2O3 to the Mn-Ce/TiO2 showed the manganese reduction peaks at 406°C. The peak at 554°C is probably associated with reduction of the surface oxygen of ceria [39,40]. Previous study showed that the reduction of iron species in Fe2O3/TiO2 showed a reduction peak at 387°C [41]. This peak is moved to 493°C in Mn-Ce-Fe/TiO2. After substitution of the NiO species, the manganese reduction peak is shifted from 417 to 395°C. The peak of reduction of the surface oxygen of ceria is shifted to 567°C. The Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 showed the highest shift of the manganese reduction temperature, and could be an indication of positive interaction between the titania support and the manganese-nickel oxide species [42,43]. This interaction is beneficial to an enhancement of the oxygen mobility. Fig. 10 shows the manganese reduction peak is shifted leftward after substitution of the K2O species. It could be seen that the catalysts doped K2O enhanced the oxidation state of Mn on the surface of the catalysts. Manganese oxides attract interest due to its high SCR activity at low temperature [44,45]. These results are in good agreement with that of SCR activity. Manganese oxides contain various types of labile oxygen, which are necessary to complete a catalytic cycle [46,47]. 3.6 NH3-TPD analysis The acid site in which NH3 is adsorbed is a key factor in the performance of the catalyst. Figs. 11 and 12 show NH3-TPD curves for Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-M-K/TiO2 catalysts. One broad desorption peak spanned in the temperature range of 150–440°C is present for three catalysts which are attributed to NH3 desorbed by weak acid and Brønsted acid sites. With increasing desorption temperature, the temperature range of 570–680°C is attributed to the quantity of chemisorbed NH3 molecules adsorbed by Lewis acid sites [48]. A significant change of the desorption curve can be observed after doping with K. The quantity of weak acid sites decreased gradually and the quantity of strong acid sites increased, which implies that doping with K deeply influences the conversation between weak and strong acid sites. The decrease of the weak acid sites is one of the main reasons for the activity decrease after doping with K. 3.7 DRIFT studies Fig. 13 showed the DRIFT spectra of Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 catalysts treated in 500ppm NH3 for 30min at 180°C. Several bands at 1602, 1604, 1436, 1434, 1293, 1297, 1290cm−1 and a broad band in the range of 1850–1661cm−1 were detected. The bands at 1602, 1604, 1293, 1297, 1290cm−1 could be attributed to coordinate NH3 on Lewis acid sites [49]. The bands at 1436, 1434cm−1 and in the range of 1850–1661cm−1 could be attributed to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites [50]. NH stretching vibration modes at 3159, 3162, 3164, 3369, 3366, 3376cm−1 also showed up [51]. After doped with K2O, the DRIFT spectra of three catalysts is showed in Fig. 14 . Some negative bands at 3682, 3649, 3673cm−1 ascribed to OH stretching vibration modes due to the interaction of surface hydroxyl with NH3 [52] were formed. The intensity of the bands due to NH3 and NH4 + species decreased, of which 1850–1661cm−1could be attributed to Brønsted acid sites to reduce the most. Figs. 15 and 16 showed the DRIFT spectra of Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-M-K/TiO2catalysts treated in NO/He for 30min at 180°C. After 500ppm NO was passed over the sample, bands at 1274, 1442, 1437, 1579, 1585, 1621cm−1could be detected. The bands at 1442, 1437cm−1 could be attributed to monodentate nitrate on manganese oxides [53]. The bands at 1579, 1585, 1274cm−1 assigned to bidentate nitrate formed on manganese oxides were detected [54]. A band at 1621cm−1 due to bridged nitrate on Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 catalyst had appeared. After doped with K2O, the bands at 1258, 1264, 1284cm−1 due to bidentate nitrate and 1659, 1642, 1665cm−1 due to bridged nitrate were detected. The bands at 1579, 1585cm−1 due to bidentate nitrate on Mn-Ce/TiO2 and Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 catalysts were disappeared. The nitrate species including bridging nitrate and bidentate nitrate formed on the Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 catalysts, playing a major role in the SCR reaction at 180°C. K+ cation cause nitrate species change. The presence of potassium ions to form the competitive adsorption hindered the normal of the catalytic reaction. Fig. 17 showed K+ poisoning process of the catalyst. The addition of alkali metal will reduce the number of oxygen vacancy and adsorption of ammonia and nitric oxide. It is well understood that the poisoning mechanism occurs via chemical bonding of the K+ cation to the MOH sites, the so-called Brønsted acid sites. These sites are responsible for the adsorption of ammonia on the catalyst surface, which constitutes the first step in the SCR reaction mechanism. In the presence of K+ cation, MOK complexes are formed, thereby stopping the acid cycle. 4 Conclusions In this study, the NO conversion of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation method exhibited excellent catalytic activity under the influence of alkali metals or not. With the addition of transition metals, the NO conversion can achieve nearly 85% at the temperature of 150°C. The activity of the catalysts doped with K is 85% at the temperature of 300°C with the addition of NiO. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, XPS, DRIFT, TPD and TPR. According to the results, the existence of Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO2 in catalysts might be present in an amorphous state. The surface area and pore volume were higher but decreased with doping K+ cation. It indicated that potassium ions adsorbed on the catalyst surface inhibited the action. The addition of alkali metal leading to deactivation of the catalysts, the reasons are that the deposition of KNO3 not only reduces the surface area and pore volume but also reduces the surface chemisorbed oxygen causing a decline in Brønsted acid sites. Due to potassium ions occupy the oxygen vacancy, the adsorption oxygen concentration of catalyst surface decreases, thereby stopping the acid cycle. coredata.dc:description: Alkali metals were considered to be poisonous to not only V-based catalysts but also Mn-based catalysts. Catalysts of Mn-Ce-M/TiO2 (M=Fe, Ni) prepared by co-precipitation method for low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3 under the influence of alkali metals were investigated in this study. As the experiment result, the low temperature SCR activity showed greatly enhanced which near at 150°C the substitution of the Fe content to Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst could obviously increased to 87% without alkali metals and the best NO conversion of Mn-Ce-Ni/TiO2 catalyst under alkali metals in the temperature range of 150–300°C was 88% (K/Mn=0.5). The addition of alkali metal not only generates physical adsorption but also reduces the surface chemisorbed oxygen and causes a decline in Brønsted acid sites. These catalysts showed higher SCR activity and better resistance to alkali poisoning, because the characteristics of the large surface area and pore volume, the increased chemisorbed oxygen, the enhanced oxidative ability of manganese species and the presence of many weak acid sites.
coredata.dc:title: The influence of K+ cation on the MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 at low temperature
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
